text: Peacock & Chinkara Breeding Centre, Jhabuwa is a 750-acre protected peacock (Indian peafowl) and chinkara reserve forest in Jhabuwa village 15 km south of Bawal in Rewari district in the Indian state of Haryana. Jhabuwa is from Delhi and from Gurugram and 200 km from Hisar. ==History== This centre of Forests Department, Haryana was officially opened on 4 October 2011 by then Chief Minister, Om Prakash Chautala. The state government will be providing about Rs.20 crore of funding for the centre over the next 20 years. ==Reserve forest== The Jhabuwa reserve forest lies between Jhabuwa, Bidawas, Bhadoj and Khijuri villages. Out of 750 acres reserve forest, 80 acres are allocated for the captive breeding of Chinkara and Indian peafowl. 20 Peaocks were tagged, with the help of Bombay Natural History Society, on legs and wing for the long-term study of movement and health. Those were released in the wild in February 2018.20 tagged peacocks to be released in the wild for long-term study , Hindustan Times, 22 Feb 2018. ==See also== * Masani barrage * CCS HAU, Bawal campus ==References== Category:Rewari district Category:Tourism in Haryana Category:Wildlife sanctuaries in Haryana * Category:Pavo (genus) Category:Bird sanctuaries of India Category:Zoos in Haryana
